# Understanding distribution

.bql[
Understanding the distribution of the data is useful for several reasons:

- Descriptive analysis:
- Data quality:
- Assumption checking:
- Interpretation of results: 
- Visualization:
]

---

class: middle

# Distribution 

.bql[

.green-h["The distribution of the variable Y"]

- describes its center, variability and shape
- use both numbers and graphics

]



---

class: middle

# Center: Mean or Average

.bql[
.b[Mean:] average value in a sample or population

- $\bar{y} = \dfrac{\sum_{i=1}^ny_i}{n}$ is an average of $n$ values $y_i$ in a sample
- $\mu$ is an average value of $y$ in a population
]

---

class: middle

# Student Survey 


```{r}
survey <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/deepbas/statdatasets/main/StudentSurvey.csv")
mean(survey$Pulse) # the command `mean` computes an average
```

.hljs[
The mean pulse rate for this sample of students is $\bar{y} = 69.6$ beats per minute.
]

---

# Center: Median
.bql[
.bold[Median:] the middle value when the data are ordered
- The median splits the data in half
- $m$ is the median value in a sample
- $M$ is the median value in a population
]

```{r}
median(survey$Pulse) # the command `median` computes an median
```


.hljs[
The median pulse rate for this sample of students is $m = 70$ beats per minute. 
]

---

# Variability: Standard Deviation

.bql[
Standard Devation (SD): average value in a sample or population
- $s = \sqrt{ \dfrac{\sum_{i=1}^n(y_i - \overline{y})^2}{n-1}}$ is the SD of $n$ values $y_i$ in a sample
- $\sigma$ is the SD of values of $y$ in a population
]

```{r}
sd(survey$Pulse) # the command `sd` computes an average
```


.hljs[
The SD of pulse rates for this sample of students is $s = 12.2$ beats per minute. The "average" deviation of individual pulse rates around the mean value is about 12.2 beats per minute.
]

---

class: middle

# Shape: histogram

.bqt[.bold[Histogram:] aggregates values into bins and counts how many cases fall into each bin]

.pull-left[

.code80[
```{r, echo = FALSE, fig.height=3.5, out.width="70%", fig.align='center'}
ggplot(survey, aes(x = Pulse)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5) +
  labs(
    title = "Histogram of pulse rates",
    x = "Pulse",
    y = "Count"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 7),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 7)
  )
```
]
]
.pull-right[
.bql.font80[
- Pulse rates are .bold[symmetrically] distributed around a rate of about 70 beats per minute.

- Symmetric distributions are "centered" around a mean and median that are roughly the same in value.

]
]

## Adding a categorical variable: stats

.bql.font70[Use `group_by()` and `summarise()` to get summary statistics using `dplyr` package to compare distributions across different levels of a categorical variable
]


```{r}
survey %>%
  group_by(Smoke) %>%
  summarise(
    Min = min(Pulse, na.rm = TRUE),
    Q1 = quantile(Pulse, 0.25, na.rm = TRUE),
    Median = median(Pulse, na.rm = TRUE),
    Mean = mean(Pulse, na.rm = TRUE),
    Q3 = quantile(Pulse, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE),
    Max = max(Pulse, na.rm = TRUE),
    SD = sd(Pulse, na.rm = TRUE),
    N = n() )
```


.hljs[
Pulse rate stats by smoking status: Smoker have a slightly higher mean pulse rate than non-smokers (71.8 vs. 69.3).
]

class: middle

# Shape: data distribution

.bql[
If a distribution of data is .bold[approximately bell-shaped], about 95% of the data should fall within two standard deviations of the sample mean.

- for a sample: 95% of values between $\bar{y} - 2s$ and $\bar{y} + 2s$
- for a population: 95% of values between $\mu - 2\sigma$ and $\mu + 2\sigma$
]

# Standardizing data: z-score

.bqt.font90[The z-score of a data value, x, tells us how many standard deviations the value is above or below the mean:

$$z = \dfrac{x - \text{mean}}{\text{SD}}$$]

<br>

- E.g. if a value $x$ has $z=-1.5$ then the value $x$ is .bold[1.5 standard deviations below] the mean.

.bql[.bold[Question:] If we standardize all values in a bell-shaped distribution, 95% of all z-scores fall between what values?]

class: middle

# Shape and Stats: Quartiles

.bql.font80[
.bold[Quartiles] divide values in to quarters

- 1st Quartile: $Q_1$ is the 25th percentile
- 2nd Quartile: $Q_2$ is the 50th percentile (median)
- 3rd Quartile: $Q_3$ is the 75th percentile

.bold[5-number summary] is quartiles along with min and max: $\text{min}, Q_1, \text{m}, Q_3, \text{max}$

.bold[Interquartile Range (IQR)] is the range of the middle 50% of values:
- $IQR = Q_3 - Q_1$
- the .bold[range] is just $\text{max} - \text{min}$
]

---

# Shape and Stats: Quartiles

```{r}
summary(survey$Pulse)
```

.bql.font90[
The 5-number summary is

- $\text{min} = 35.00, Q_1 = 62.00, \text{m}=70.00, Q_3 = 77.75, \text{max} = 130.0$
- right skewed:  variation is upper 25 of movies is much larger than lower 25% 

  - upper range: $\text{max} - Q_3 = 1328.1 - 173.7 = 1154.4$
  - lower range: $Q_1 - \text{min} = 30.7 - 0.025 = 30.675$
]

---

# Shape and Stats: Boxplot
.bql.font70[
.bold[Boxplot:] Visualization of 5-number summary

- Draw a numerical scale appropriate for the data
- Draw a box stretching from $Q_1$ to $Q_3$
- Divide the box with a line at the median
- Draw a line from each quartile to the most extreme data value that is not an outlier
- Identify each outlier individually by plotting with a symbol such as an asterisk or dot
]

--

<br>

.bq.font80[.yellow-h[Outlier rule of thumb:] cases that are more extreme than

$$
Q_1 - 1.5(IQR) \ \ \ \ \text{or} \ \ \ \ Q_3 + 1.5(IQR)
$$
]

---

# Shape and Stats: Boxplot

.pull-left.font80[
  
```{r, fig.height=3}
ggplot(data = survey, aes(x = 1, y = Pulse)) + 
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(x = "", y = "pulse rate") + coord_flip()
```

]

.pull-right.font80[

```{r}
summary(survey$Pulse)
```

.bq.font80[
- $IQR = 77.75-62 = 15.75$
- $1.5(15.75) = 23.625$
- lower "fence" = $62-23.625=  38.375$
- upper "fence" = $77.75+23.625=  101.375$
]
```{r}
which(survey$Pulse < 38.375)
which(survey$Pulse > 101.375)
```

]
